0.user_question: Juan asked his neighbor, Herb, how much his house was worth. Herb answered that he paid $76,000 for the house. If Juan's house is 30% less expensive than Herb's, calculate the value of the two houses combined.

direct_answer.text: Firstly we need to find out how much Juan’s house costs which can be found using this formula (Herb_house price) × 0.7 because it says “less” so you use .7 instead of full %. This would mean ($76,000 )×  0.7= $(53,200). To get the sum amount just add both prices together ($53,200+$76,000)=$129,200. Therefore, their properties when put together cost $\(129,200 \)$.

0.user_question: Juan asked his neighbor, Herb, how much his house was worth. Herb answered that he paid $76,000 for the house. If Juan's house is 30% less expensive than Herb's, calculate the value of the two houses combined.

ost_step.1: First we need to find out how much Juan’s house costs which is 30% cheaper than Herb's one. subanswer.text: Since Juan’s house costs 30% less than Herb’s, then it costs 76,000 * (1 - 30%) = 76,000 * 0.7 = \$53,200. Hence, the decreased rate when referring back to 'percentage points', one finds that Juan pays an additional 30% off (\$22,800/$53,200*100%=~43%). 0.user_question: Juan asked his neighbor, Herb, how much his house was worth. Herb answered that he paid $76,000 for the house. If Juan's house is 30% less expensive than Herb's, calculate the value of the two houses combined.

ost_step.1: First we need to find out how much Juan’s house costs which is 30% cheaper than Herb's one. To get this amount you subtract (30/100) * $76,000 from itself resulting into ($76,000 – (30/100)*$76,000)= $53,200. This means Juan spent only half as much money on his home compared to what it cost Hisbert when he bought him. Therefore if their homes add up together then($76,000+53,200= )*1=$129,200*. direct_answer.text: Let's break down the problem step by step according to the hint provided. We first want to determine the difference in prices due to the percentage reduction mentioned; specifically, calculating 30% off of Herb's original purchase price. Calculate 30% of Herb's expenditure using the formula $(30 / 100) \times \$76,000$, yielding $\$22,800$. Subtract this resultant figure from Herb's initial investment to obtain Juan's property value, i.e., $\$76,000 - \$22,800 = \$53,200$. With these values known, combine them by adding John's and Herb's respective expenses ($\$76,000 + \$53,200$) leading us to $\$129,200$. As such, combining all possible factors related to pricing yields our solution being roughly equivalent to "$\$129,200".
